items.title: DOGE axes CISA ‘red team’ staffers amid ongoing federal cuts
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) has laid off over a hundred employees from CISA, including red team staffers.
- Layoffs occurred in late February and early March, with affected employees cut immediately without prior warning.
- More than 80 employees in continuous monitoring and 30-50 in incident response were affected, marking the third known round of layoffs at CISA since January 20.

items.title: Podcast app Pocket Casts makes its web player free
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Pocket Casts, a podcast app owned by Automattic, has made its web player free to use.
- Users can stream episodes without a subscription or account, but can create a free account for additional features.
- The company's Pocket Casts Plus subscription offers extra tools and customization options.
- Unlike competitors, Pocket Casts does not use AI-driven content suggestions, promoting user choice instead.
- Free streaming will also be available on Pocket Casts’ Mac and Windows apps, challenging services like Apple Podcasts.

items.title: Flower Labs’ launches a new service that automatically switches from local to cloud AI
Yet another AI robotics firm lands major funding, as Dexterity closes latest round
Geothermal could power nearly all new data centers through 2030
OpenAI launches new tools to help businesses build AI agents
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- OpenAI released new tools for developers and businesses to build AI agents using its own AI models.
- The tools are part of the new Responses API, replacing the old Assistants API.
- The hype around AI agents has increased, but technical challenges remain for adoption and usability.
- New offerings include highly accurate web search models (GPT-4o search and GPT-4o mini search) and a file search utility for company databases.
- OpenAI introduced an open-source Agents SDK for integrating models and monitoring AI agent activities.
- OpenAI aims for 2025 to be a pivotal year for AI agents in the workforce.

items.title: Mark Cuban says AI is ‘never the answer,’ it’s a ‘tool’
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Mark Cuban spoke at the SXSW conference about AI's role in aiding small businesses.
- He emphasized that AI should serve as a tool, not an answer by itself.
- Cuban encouraged entrepreneurs to learn about AI to leverage its potential in business.

items.title: Hugging Face expands its LeRobot platform with training data for self-driving machines
Waymo expands its robotaxi service across Silicon Valley
Virtual physical therapists Hinge Health files for IPO, estimated to raise $500M
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Hinge Health is a company focused on treating chronic musculoskeletal conditions digitally and has filed for an IPO.
- The company aims to raise up to $500 million, although share pricing has not yet been announced.
- In 2024, Hinge's revenue was $390 million, a 33% increase from the previous year, with narrowed net losses of $11.9 million.
- Hinge employs advanced wearable sensors and computer vision technology monitored by a professional team to help reduce MSK pain.
- Previously valued at $6.2 billion in October 2021, Hinge has raised a total of $828 million in venture capital.
- Insight Partners and Atomico are the largest outside shareholders, holding 19% and 15% respectively.

items.title: BaaS startup Synctera raises $15M, signs Bolt as a customer
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
• Synctera has raised $15 million in a Series A extension funding round, bringing total raised to $94 million since its inception in 2020.
• Key customers include Bolt, Webull, and others, with 416,000 end users on its platform.
• Company experienced an 80% revenue increase and a 230% gross profit increase year-over-year for the fiscal year ending January 31.
• Synctera aims to achieve breakeven by early 2026 and plans to expand its sales team and product development.
• A strategic partnership with Hawk has been formed to combat financial crimes.

items.title: The sibling founders of Stax Payments are back with a new fintech and a $20M seed raise
items.author: Sal Rehmetullah, Suneera Madhani
items.summary:
- Worth raised $20 million in seed funding to streamline underwriting for small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs).
- Founded by siblings Sal Rehmetullah and Suneera Madhani, who previously established Stax Payments, which had a valuation over $1.1 billion.
- The aim is to provide a seamless application process for credit-based products, reducing paperwork and application times significantly.
- Worth uses AI and a strategic partnership with Equifax to analyze over 242 million global SMBs.
- Currently, Worth has over 25 clients and aims to launch a business credit score in early 2026.

items.title: FTC says Americans lost $12.5B to scams last year — social media, AI and crypto didn’t help
TikTok now lets parents see their teen’s follower/following list, block access during certain hours
Trump nominates Sean Plankey as new CISA director
EU AI Act: Latest draft Code for AI model makers tiptoes towards gentler guidance for Big AI
Meet the new VC firm secretly backed by Volkswagen
Learn what VCs want to see from founders at TechCrunch Sessions: AI
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- AI startups saw a dramatic funding increase of 62% to $110 billion in 2024, amidst a general decline in startup funding.
- Investors are prioritizing startups that demonstrate real-world applications and long-term profitability over merely having 'AI' in their names.
- At TechCrunch Sessions: AI on June 5 at UC Berkeley, VCs Zeya Yang, Jill Chase, and Kanu Gulati will share insights on what they seek in startups at various investment stages from seed to Series C.

items.title: Musk’s Starlink to launch in India through Airtel
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Airtel partners with SpaceX to launch Starlink's satellite internet services in India.
- Services depend on receiving regulatory approvals from IN-SPACe and the Department of Telecommunications.
- SpaceX has previously faced issues for starting service rollouts without licenses.
- Airtel plans to sell Starlink equipment through its stores and offer services to business customers.
- Indian government has made moves to facilitate satellite services, including a new telecom bill in late 2023.
- Starlink aims to enhance Airtel's product offerings to provide reliable broadband across India.

items.title: Junction, an API to link health wearables with labs, raises $18M
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- Junction, formerly known as Vital, raised $18 million in Series A funding led by [Creandum](https://creandum.com/).  
- The company provides an API to integrate health wearables with laboratory services to improve healthcare outcomes.  
- Junction's platform connects over 500 devices and plans to facilitate a million lab tests this year across 50 US states.

items.title: General Fusion fires up its newest steampunk fusion reactor
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- General Fusion has successfully created plasma inside its prototype reactor, Lawson Machine 26 (LM26).
- This achievement marks the start of a 93-week quest to demonstrate the viability of their steampunk fusion approach.
- The reactor was assembled in 16 months and aims to reach breakeven by 2026.
- General Fusion, founded in 2002, has raised $440 million and is one of the oldest fusion companies still operational.
- Important milestones for fusion involve commercial and scientific breakeven; only the U.S. Department of Energy's National Ignition Facility has achieved scientific breakeven.
- General Fusion's magnetized target fusion (MTF) differs from traditional methods, using steam-driven pistons rather than lasers.
- LM26 currently lacks a liquid lithium wall, utilizing solid lithium, which limits testing capabilities.

items.title: Zolve, a neobank for global citizens moving to the US, raises $51M and secures $200M debt
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Zolve, a neobank for global citizens relocating to the U.S., raised $251 million to expand its services.
- The startup provides financial services without requiring U.S. credit history, using home country credit data.
- Zolve aims to introduce loans and expand operations to Canada, the UK, and Australia in the next year.

items.title: Sola emerges from stealth with $30M to build the ‘Stripe for security’
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Sola has developed a low/no-code platform for creating custom cybersecurity apps.
- The startup has secured $30 million in seed funding to enhance its services.
- Co-founders Guy Flechter and Ron Peled aim to democratize security app development.
- They propose a third option for security solutions, combining features of commercial and open-source tools.
- The platform utilizes AI and big data to assist users without extensive technical skills.
- It offers capabilities for querying existing security app data and includes pre-made apps for various functions.

items.title: Some say passkeys are clunky — this startup wants to change that
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Passwords are common but insecure, leading to many data breaches due to stolen credentials.
- Passkeys are being promoted by major tech companies like Amazon, Apple, Google, and Microsoft as a secure alternative to passwords.
- Users find passkeys cumbersome, prompting the startup Hawcx to develop a new passwordless authentication technology to address usability issues.
- Hawcx's solution generates private keys each time a user signs in, avoiding the need to store keys on devices.
- The startup, founded by Riya Shanmugam and others, has raised $3 million in pre-seed funding and is starting pilot programs with large banks and gaming companies.
- Experts express optimism about Hawcx’s technology addressing the limitations of passkeys, particularly around device dependency and usability issues.

items.title: Equator closes $55M fund to bring more private capital to African climate tech
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- African venture capital firm [Equator](https://equator.vc/) raised $55 million for its first fund targeting early-stage climate tech startups in Africa.
- The fund aims to bridge funding gaps by attracting private capital, with plans to invest in 15 to 18 startups, providing $750,000 to $1 million for Seed stage and up to $2 million for Series A.
- Equator's investors include DFIs such as British International Investment, and foundations like the Global Energy Alliance for People and Planet, indicating a reliance on traditional funding sources despite efforts to wean startups off aid.
- The firm emphasizes the importance of economic value alongside development impact in the climate tech sector, highlighting a shift in investor focus towards profitability and scalable ventures.
- Equator plans to assist startups with governance, unit economics, and mobilizing additional investments from LPs while aiming for strategic exits and reduced equity dilution through proper capital structuring.

items.title: Apple’s next major OS updates will bring the biggest design overhaul in years
items.summary:
- Apple's iOS 19, iPadOS 19, and macOS 16 will feature substantial design changes, the most significant in years.
- The new design will refresh various UI elements like icons, menus, and buttons, aiming to simplify navigation.
- The revamp is expected to draw inspiration from VisionOS, featuring circular icons and translucent panels.
- Plans for the updates will be revealed at Apple's Worldwide Developer Conference (WWDC) in June 2025.

items.title: Reshape Energy is using an acquisition playbook to drive energy upgrades for commercial real estate
items.summary:
- Reshape Energy aims to accelerate the decarbonization of commercial real estate by selling energy system upgrades.
- The startup is based in Munich and was founded in May 2024 by a team with experience in energy businesses.
- It focuses on lower-carbon heating solutions such as heat pumps and solar panels in response to regulatory pressure in Europe.
- Reshape Energy adopts an acquisition model to integrate existing companies in the sector and expand its service offerings.
- The company recently secured €5 million in funding for further acquisitions and operational expansion.
- CEO Benjamin Stanzl emphasized the need for a joined-up approach to overcome the inertia associated with energy upgrades in commercial properties.

items.title: Meet the new VC firm secretly backed by Volkswagen
items.summary:
- A new venture firm, [Leitmotif](https://leitmotif.vc/), has been funded by Volkswagen, committing $300 million to its first fund.
- Leitmotif has invested in around 20 startups with a focus on decarbonization, including companies in EV, space, and nuclear fusion sectors.
- The firm's investment strategy allocates 70% of capital to U.S. startups, targeting existing problems in billion-dollar markets, while 30% is aimed at revolutionary innovations for the future.

items.title: Startup studio Hexa acquires majority stake in Veevart, a vertical SaaS platform for museums
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Hexa, a Paris-based startup studio, acquires majority stake in Veevart, a SaaS company for museums.
- Veevart offers solutions for ticketing, fundraising, CRM, and collection management, serving 160 museums worldwide.
- Hexa invests €5 million ($5.4 million) and aims to help Veevart reach $20 million in annual recurring revenue.

items.title: Radiology AI software provider Gleamer expands into MRI with two small acquisitions
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Gleamer, a French startup, expands into MRI after developing AI tools for X-rays and mammographies.
- The company has acquired two startups: [Pixyl](https://pixyl.ai/) and [Caerus Medical](https://caerusmedical.com/).
- Gleamer aims to enhance diagnostic accuracy in medical imaging and has processed 35 million examinations globally, receiving CE and FDA certifications for its products.
- CEO Christian Allouche highlighted the complexity of MRI tasks including segmentation and characterization, prompting the acquisitions to expedite technology development. 
- The new acquisitions will establish Gleamer's platforms for MRI, with a goal to cover various use cases in the next 2-3 years.
- Gleamer’s mammography model currently detects 80% of cancers, outperforming human radiologists but indicating room for improvement.

items.title: Infinite Uptime bags $35M to help factories optimize equipment usage
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Infinite Uptime, an Indian startup, raised $35 million in a Series C funding round.
- The funding aims to expand its presence in the U.S. and other markets.
- The company provides predictive maintenance solutions for factories using proprietary sensors and AI-based diagnostics.
- Infinite Uptime's solutions have resulted in a cumulative downtime savings of 74,274 hours and improvements in productivity, energy efficiency, safety, and compliance by 5% to 10%.
- The startup serves 800 plants across nearly 30 countries and has plans for further growth in product development and research.

items.title: Asana CEO Dustin Moskovitz is retiring
items.summary:
- Dustin Moskovitz is retiring from Asana, the company he founded in 2008.
- His retirement was announced in the company’s fiscal fourth-quarter earnings report.
- Moskovitz plans to transition to a chair role after the new CEO is appointed.
- Asana has raised over $450 million in venture funding and went public in 2020.
- Prior to Asana, Moskovitz co-founded Meta (formerly Facebook).

items.title: Elon Musk says DOGE involvement is making it harder to run his businesses
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Elon Musk mentioned that his work with DOGE is complicating the management of his businesses including Tesla and SpaceX.
- Critics claim DOGE has overpromised on spending cuts and its online record contains inaccuracies.
- Cybersecurity experts warn that DOGE's methods may compromise national data security by accessing government data insecurely.
- DOGE has significantly reduced oversight on organizations impacting Musk's companies, including the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
- Musk affirmatively stated he would continue his involvement with DOGE for another year during the interview.

items.title: Eric Schmidt joins Relativity Space as CEO
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Former Google CEO Eric Schmidt becomes CEO of Relativity Space.
- Schmidt made a significant investment and took a controlling stake in the company.
- He succeeds co-founder Tim Ellis, who will continue as a board director.
- Relativity Space is preparing for the 2026 launch of Terran R, aiming to compete with SpaceX’s Falcon 9.
- The company has secured nearly $3 billion in launch contracts in anticipation of Terran R's launch.
- Schmidt's experience may help guide the startup through critical moments and government relations.
- Relativity Space uses innovative techniques like 3D printing and AI in rocket production.
- The company faced challenges with cash shortages and previously discontinued its Terran 1 rocket to focus on Terran R.

items.title: Bluesky is weighing a proposal that gives users consent over how their data is used for AI
In another chess move with Microsoft, OpenAI is pouring $12B into CoreWeave
Rad Power Bikes CEO steps down
Bluesky now lets users upload videos that are up to 3 minutes long
Open web initiatives Project Liberty and Solid could be teaming up
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Project Liberty and Solid may collaborate to improve control over digital identities and data.
- Frank McCourt spoke at SXSW 2025, indicating ongoing discussions with Tim Berners-Lee.
- Although no formal partnership has been established, future integration of Solid Pods into Project Liberty is being considered.
- Berners-Lee supports Project Liberty's efforts and has backed its bid for TikTok.
- Currently, Project Liberty is focused on developing the Decentralized Social Networking Protocol (DSNP), which is being adopted by various apps.

items.title: What PowerSchool won’t say about its data breach affecting millions of students
items.summary:
- PowerSchool, a major U.S. edtech provider, disclosed a significant data breach in January 2025, potentially affecting millions of students and staff.
- The breach, caused by a single compromised credential, allowed access to sensitive student information stored in its systems, which are used by over 18,000 schools.
- As of now, PowerSchool has not confirmed the number of individuals affected, though reports suggest over 62 million students' data may have been compromised.
- The nature of the stolen data remains unclear, but it is reported to include personal information, grades, attendance records, and possibly Social Security numbers.
- There are ongoing concerns regarding the ransom paid to hackers and whether the stolen data has been fully deleted, with no clear evidence provided by PowerSchool.

items.title: Poolside CEO says most companies shouldn’t build foundation models
items.author: Jason Warner, Becca Szkutak
items.summary:
- Jason Warner, CEO of Poolside, believes most companies should focus on building applications, not foundation models.
- He spoke at the [HumanX AI conference](https://www.humanx.co/) and stressed the importance of intelligence.
- Warner argues that foundation models should be part of a larger product strategy, not the sole focus.
- Poolside aims to develop AGI through software, targeting challenging fields like defense and planning a consumer application.
- Poolside, founded in 2023, has raised over $620 million and is valued at $3 billion.

items.title: DeepSeek isn’t taking VC money yet. Here are 3 reasons why.
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- DeepSeek’s founder, Liang Wenfeng, prefers to retain control and has not accepted outside investments despite strong VC interest.
- The startup is uniquely self-funded through profits from Liang’s hedge fund, High-Flyer, which alleviates the need for external funding.
- Accepting funding from Chinese investors could exacerbate existing trust and privacy concerns, risking further bans from governments and companies.

items.title: At SXSW, Bluesky CEO Jay Graber pokes fun at Mark Zuckerberg with Latin phrase T-shirt
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Bluesky CEO Jay Graber wore a T-shirt with the phrase 'Mundus sine caesaribus' at SXSW 2025, mocking Mark Zuckerberg’s 'Aut Zuck aut nihil'.
- Graber's shirt suggests a world without centralized control, contrasting Bluesky’s decentralized platform with Meta’s legacy systems.
- Bluesky is nearing 33 million users, while Meta boasts 3.35 billion daily active users, emphasizing the challenges ahead for Bluesky.

items.title: Daqus Energy has a plan to make EV sports cars fast, light, and cheap
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Daqus Energy introduces a new battery material called TAQ, designed to be cheaper, lighter, and denser than existing options.
- The company has raised $6 million in seed funding, aiming to develop TAQ for electric vehicles (EVs).
- TAQ cathodes use carbon-based compounds, avoiding costly minerals like nickel or cobalt, and are produced with significantly less energy.
- Internal tests show TAQ batteries are durable, capable of 2,000 charge cycles maintaining at least 80% capacity and enabling six-minute fast charging.
- The material's lightweight nature could help electric sports cars achieve better performance and handling, addressing the weight penalty of electrification.

items.title: Elon Musk says X is down due to cyberattacks
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's platform X was inaccessible for thousands of users on Monday morning, particularly in the U.S.
- Musk reported a "massive cyberattack" that the platform is facing near 5:30 a.m. ET, with over 20,000 users initially reporting issues.
- The outages, which lasted for about eight hours, were attributed to a coordinated attack possibly involving a large group or a country.
- Issues continued past 1:30 PM ET, despite some users intermittently accessing the platform later in the day.

items.title: Open social web browser Surf integrates with Bluesky in latest beta
items.summary:
- Surf, the open social web browser from Flipboard, integrates with Bluesky's social network.
- Users can log in with Bluesky credentials and access feeds like following, discover, and custom feeds.
- The new version, "Blue Wave," allows interactions like liking and replying to Bluesky posts directly in Surf.
- Features a setup wizard for custom home feeds, allowing users to combine feeds from Bluesky and Mastodon.
- Users can filter out unwanted content, including options to hide political topics.
- Aims to unify the social web and promote alternatives to centralized social media platforms.
- The beta was first shown at SXSW and is expanding its tester base while preparing to launch a web version.

items.title: Insight VC explains the biggest mistake that keeps founders from raising a big round
items.summary:
- VC Insight Partners emphasizes that financial infrastructure is crucial for startups, particularly beyond customer acquisition metrics.
- Founders should provide detailed financial documents and customer records to satisfy potential investors during diligence.
- Insight Partners has shifted to investing over a billion dollars per quarter, highlighting the changing dynamics of funding in post-pandemic times.

items.title: Hacker accessed PowerSchool’s network months before massive December breach
What to know about TikTok’s uncertain future in the US and the people who want to buy it
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- TikTok, owned by ByteDance, is facing uncertainty in the US due to data privacy concerns and a potential ban.
- Investors are competing to purchase TikTok, with a valuation potentially exceeding $60 billion.
- The TikTok ban saga began in August 2020 when an executive order was signed by Trump, leading to a series of legal battles.
- In early 2023, the U.S. Supreme Court upheld a ban on TikTok, but the app briefly shut down before resuming operations the same day.
- Donald Trump has recently expressed support for keeping TikTok operational in the U.S., surprising many.
- Various investment groups, including The People’s Bid and an American investor consortium, are vying to buy TikTok.
- Other interested parties include Bobby Kotick, Steven Mnuchin, and major corporations like Oracle and Microsoft.

items.title: Following takedown operation, Garantex invites customers to ‘face-to-face’ Moscow meeting
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Russian crypto exchange Garantex experienced a significant setback following Tether blocking access to $28 million in funds.
- U.S. law enforcement seized Garantex's official websites and charged two administrators for facilitating money laundering.
- Garantex is inviting customers with positive account balances to face-to-face meetings in Moscow to discuss solutions for blocked assets, despite risks involved in attending.
